revision.text:
{{Primary sources|date=May 2009}} The '''American Evaluation Association''' ('''AEA''') is a professional association for [[evaluators]] and those with a professional interest in the field of [[evaluation]], including [[wikt:practitioner|practitioner]]s, [[Faculty (university)|faculty]], students, funders, managers, and government decision-makers. {{as of|2014}}, AEA has approximately 7057 members from all 50 [[United States of America|US]] states and over 60 other countries. <ref name="eval.org">AEA: About Us http://www.eval.org/aboutus/organization/aboutus.asp {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090507214907/http://www.eval.org/aboutus/organization/aboutus.asp |date=2009-05-07 }}. Retrieved on 2009-05-08</ref>
== Mission ==
The American Evaluation Association's mission is to: * Improve evaluation practices and methods * Increase evaluation use * Promote evaluation as a profession and * Support the contribution of evaluation to the generation of theory and knowledge about effective human action.<ref name="eval.org" />
=== Guiding Principles for Evaluators ===
AEA Publishes the [https://web.archive.org/web/20120429201744/http://www.eval.org/Publications/GuidingPrinciples.asp AEA: Guiding Principles for Evaluators], which set expectations for evaluators in the areas of: (a) [[systematic inquiry]], (b) [[Skill|competence]], (c) [[integrity]]/honesty, (d) respect for people, and (e) responsibilities for general and [[public welfare]].
=== Publications ===
AEA sponsors two journals. The American Journal of Evaluation is published quarterly through [[SAGE Publications]] and includes individually [[peer-reviewed]] articles on a range of topics in the field.<ref>SAGE: American Journal of Evaluation http://www.sagepub.com/journalsProdDesc.nav?prodId=Journal201729. Retrieved 2009-05-01</ref> [http://www.josseybass.com/WileyCDA/Section/id-161092.html New Directions for Evaluation] is a peer-reviewed thematic [[sourcebook]] published quarterly through [[John Wiley & Sons|Jossey-Bass/Wiley]], with each issue focusing on a different topic or aspect of evaluation.
=== Topical Interest Groups ===
{{as of|2014|September}}, AEA has 51 topically-focused subgroups.<ref>AEA: About Us http://www.eval.org/aboutus/organization/tigs.asp {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090507214931/http://www.eval.org/aboutus/organization/tigs.asp |date=2009-05-07 }}. Retrieved on 2009-05-08.</ref> Each subgroup develops a strand of content for the association's annual conference, and works to build a community of practice through various means.
* [[Advocacy]] and Policy Change * Behavioral Health [formerly Alcohol, Drug Abuse, and Mental Health] * [[Assessment in Higher Education]] * Business, Leadership, and Performance * Cluster, Multi-Site and Multi-Level Evaluation * Collaborative, Participatory & Empowerment Evaluation * College Access Programs * Community Psychology * Costs, Effectiveness, Benefits, and Economics * Crime and Justice * Data Visualization and Reporting * Disabilities and Other Vulnerable Populations * Disaster and [[Emergency Management]] Evaluation * Distance Education and Other Educational Technologies * Environmental Program Evaluation * Evaluating the Arts and Culture * Evaluation Managers and Supervisors * Evaluation Policy * Evaluation Use * Extension Education Evaluation * [[Feminist]] Issues in Evaluation * Government Evaluation * Graduate Student and New Evaluators * Health Evaluation * Human Services Evaluation * Independent Consulting * [[indigenous peoples|Indigenous]] Peoples in Evaluation * Integrating Technology into Evaluation * Internal Evaluation * International and Cross-Cultural Evaluation * [[LGBT|Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender]] Issues * Mixed Methods in Evaluation * Multiethnic Issues in Evaluation * Needs Assessment * Non-Profits and Foundations Evaluation * Organizational Learning and Evaluation Capacity Building * [[Prek-12]] Educational Evaluation * Program Theory and Theory Driven Evaluation * Program Design * Qualitative Methods * Quantitative Methods: Theory and Design * Research on Evaluation * Research, Technology, and Development Evaluation * Social Network Analysis * Social Work * Stem Evaluation * Systems in Evaluation * Teaching of Evaluation * Theories of Evaluation * Translational Research Evaluation * Youth Focus Evaluation
== History == === Merger of ERS and ENet ===
In 1986, the Evaluation Research Society and Evaluation Network merged to become the American Evaluation Association. <ref>Evaluation Practice, 1986 (7), 107-110) http://aje.sagepub.com/cgi/reprint/7/1/107. Retrieved 2009-05-01</ref>
== References == <references/>
== External links == * [http://www.eval.org/ American Evaluation Association]
<!--[[Environmental Evaluation]]-->
<!--[[Category:Evaluation methods]]--> [[Category:Evaluation]] [[Category:Business organizations based in the United States]]

{{more citations needed|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox company | name = Aronson LLC | logo = Aronsonllclogo.gif | type = Private | key_people = Larry Davis, Managing Partner | industry = [[Accounting]] and [[Consultant|consulting]] | services = [[Financial audit|Audit]]
[[Tax]]
[[Consultant|Consulting]] | location = [[Rockville, Maryland]], [[United States]] | foundation = 1962 | homepage = [http://www.aronsonllc.com/ www.aronsonllc.com] }} '''Aronson LLC''' is an American [[accounting]] and [[financial consulting]] company based in [[Rockville, Maryland]]. The company employs more than 250 accountants, consultants and administrative staff, and specializes in [[financial audit]], [[tax]] and [[management consulting]] services. The company provides services for [[vertical market]]s including [[government contracting]], [[nonprofit]], [[construction]], [[real estate]], [[technology]] and [[professional services]] companies.{{Cite web|url = http://www.aronsonllc.com/our-firm/about-us|title = Aronson LLC | About Us|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} Aronson LLC is a member of Praxity, a global alliance of independent firms, organized as an international not-for-profit entity under Belgian law, with administrative office in London.{{Cite web|url=http://www.praxity.com/participating-firms/Pages/A-Z%20Directory.aspx|title=Praxity Participating Firms|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|accessdate=}} ==History== The firm was formed in 1962 by Gerald R. Aronson. With additions to management came several name changes: * In 1974, the firm was renamed Aronson, Greene, Fisher & Co., Chartered; * In 1986, the firm was renamed Aronson, Fetridge, Weigle & Stern * In 1992, the firm was renamed Aronson Fetridge, Weigle & Schimel * In 1994, the firm was renamed Aronson, Fetridge & Weigle * In 2001, the firm was renamed Aronson & Company * In 2011, the firm adopted its current name, Aronson LLC, when it changed its corporate management structure In 2004 the company established the Aronson Foundation, a [[charitable organization]]. Foundation funding comes from donations and [[philanthropic]] work by company team members, officers, clients and contacts.{{cite web|url=http://www.webcpa.com/article.cfm?articleid=4610|title=Aronson Creates Foundation Serving Childrens' Needs|date=2 June 2004|work=[[Accounting Today]]}} In 2005, Aronson merged with Capron Associates, LLP, a small [[public accounting]] firm based in [[Bethesda, Maryland]].{{cite web|url=http://www.webcpa.com/article.cfm?articleid=14567|title=Aronson & Co. Merges in Bethesda Firm|author=WebCPA staff|date=7 September 2005|work=Accounting Today}} Capron was absorbed into Aronson's organizational structure, operating under the Aronson name and moving to their Rockville offices. In 2008, the company integrated Norman A. Snyder, III, CPA's audit practice, formerly associated with Virginia's Fitzgerald, Snyder & Co., into their practice. In 2009, Aronson moved to new headquarters in Rockville. ==Affiliated companies== [http://www.aronsoncapitalpartners.com/ Aronson Capital Partners] is an [[investment bank]] providing [[mergers and acquisitions]] services, [[corporate finance]] and valuation services to middle-market companies in the [[defense industry|defense]] and [[government]] technology services industries. ==Awards and recognition== * Aronson has been continuously recognized by ''[[The Washington Post]]'' as one of the [[Washington metropolitan area|Washington, D.C. Metro area's]] "Top Workplaces."https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dre/capital-business/top-workplaces/2016 The firm was recognized for this award in 2018, 2017, 2016 and 2014.{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dre/capital-business/top-workplaces?sizeband=2|title=Top Workplaces|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|accessdate=}} * Aronson has been continuously recognized by the ''[[Washington Business Journal]]'' as one of the Washington, D.C. Metro area’s "Best Places to Work,"http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/subscriber-only/2016/06/10/best-places-to-work-large.html The firm was recognized for this award in 2018, 2017, 2016, 2014,{{Cite web|url = http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/print-edition/2014/05/09/best-places-to-work-2014-large-companies.html?page=7|title = Best Places to Work 2014: Large Companies|date = May 9, 2014|accessdate = February 5, 2015|website = Washington Business Journal|publisher = American City Business Journals|last = |first = }} 2013,{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/slideshow/2013/05/10/best-places-to-work-2013-large.html|title=Best Places to Work 2013: Large Companies|date=10 May 2013|work=Washington Business Journal}} 2012,{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/datacenter/best-places-to-work-2012-master-list.html|title=Best Places to Work 2012: The Companies|date=1 June 2012|work=Washington Business Journal}} 2008,{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/event/3916/|title=Best Places to Work 2008|work=Washington Business Journal}} and 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/event/3177|title=Best Places to Work 2007|work=Washington Business Journal}} * Aronson has been continuously recognized by ''INSIDE Public Accounting'' as a "Top 100 Firm." The firm was recognized for these awards in 2018, 2017, 2016, 2015, 2014,{{cite web|url=http://insidepublicaccounting.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/INSIDE-Public-Accounting_2014-Best-of-the-Best.pdf|title=The 2014 IPA Best of the Best Firms|work=Inside Public Accounting}}{{Cite web|url = http://blog.insidepublicaccounting.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/INSIDE-Public-Accounting_August_2014_WEB_FINAL1.pdf|title = IPA Special Report - The 2014 IPA 100 Firms|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} 2013, 2012, and previous years. * Aronson has been continuously recognized by ''[[Accounting Today]]'' as a "Top 100 Firm" and "Capital Region Leader." The firm was recognized for these awards in 2018, 2017, 2016, 2015, 2014,{{Cite web|url = http://digital.accountingtoday.com/accountingtoday/top_100_firms_supplement_2014#pg17|title = Accounting Today 2014 Top 100 Firms|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} 2013, 2012, and previous years. * In 2016, Aronson was recognized by the [[Northern Virginia Chamber of Commerce]] as an "Outstanding Corporate Citizen" for its [[corporate social responsibility]] efforts. In 2012, the firm was a winner of the Gazette of Business & Politics Exceptional 53 awards.{{Cite web|url = http://ww2.gazette.net/PB53/|title = P&B 53|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} In 2010, the company won the Montgomery County Chamber's Corporate Social Responsibility Award.{{Cite web|url = http://montgomerycountychamber.com/events/business-awards-dinner/about-awards-and-past-winners|title = Business Awards - About the Awards and Past Winners|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.aronsoncapitalpartners.com Aronson Capital Partners] * [http://www.aronsonllc.com Aronson LLC] [[Category:Accounting firms of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in Rockville, Maryland]] [[Category:Companies established in 1962]]

{{For|Other people of the same name|August Busch (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = August Anheuser Busch Sr. | image = August Anheuser Busch.jpg | caption = August A. Busch in 1925 | birth_date = {{Birth date|1865|12|29}} | birth_place = [[Saint Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]], [[Missouri]], U.S.A. | death_date = {{Death date and age|1934|02|10|1865|12|29}} | death_place = St. Louis, Missouri, U.S.A. | death_cause = Suicide by gunshot to the abdomen | occupation = [[Brewing]] | spouse = Alice Edna Zisemann | parents =Lily (Anheuser) and [[Adolphus Busch]] | children =[[Adolphus Busch III]]
Marie Busch
Alice Busch
Clara Hazel Busch Orthwein
[[Gussie Busch|August A. "Gussie" Busch Jr.]] }} '''August Anheuser Busch Sr.''' (December 29, 1865 – February 10, 1934) was an [[United States|American]] brewing magnate who served as the President and [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[Anheuser-Busch]], based in Saint Louis, Missouri, from 1913 to 1934. It became the world's largest brewery in 1957 under direction of his son [[Gussie Busch|August A. "Gussie" Busch Jr]].[http://www.immigrantentrepreneurship.org/entry.php?rec=152 Holian, Timothy J. "Adolphus Busch"], In ''Immigrant Entrepreneurship: German-American Business Biographies, 1720 to the Present,'' vol. 3, edited by Giles R. Hoyt. German Historical Institute. Last modified August 9, 2013 ==Early life== August Anheuser Busch was born on December 29, 1865, in [[St. Louis, Missouri]]. His father, [[Adolphus Busch]], was the German-born founder of Anheuser-Busch. His mother, Lilly Eberhard Anheuser, was the third daughter of brewer [[Eberhard Anheuser]], who owned the Anheuser Brewery. He had eight brothers and five sisters.{{cite news |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1913/10/11/100651720.pdf |format=pdf |title=Adolphus Busch Dies in Prussia |work= New York Times |date= October 11, 1913 |accessdate=April 23, 2013 }} ==Career== Busch became President of Anheuser-Busch in 1913, shortly after his father's death. Under his leadership, the company survived [[World War I]], [[Prohibition]], and the [[Great Depression]] by innovating and diversifying. The company delved into the production of corn products, [[baker's yeast]], [[ice cream]], [[soft drink]]s, and commercial [[refrigeration]] units to stay afloat during Prohibition. After Prohibition ended in 1933, many of these operations were discontinued. August also managed to keep Anheuser-Busch prosperous during anti-German bias of World War I. He built the Bevo Mill, about halfway between his mansion on Gravois Road and the Anheuser-Busch brewery downtown. ==Personal life== [[File:August A. Busch Children.jpg|thumb|Photograph of August A. Busch children]] Busch married Alice Ziesemann on May 8, 1890. Their children were [[Adolphus Busch III|Adolphus III]], Marie, Clara, [[August A. Busch Jr.|August Jr.]], and Alice Busch. The Busches were among prominent families who participated in the [[Veiled Prophet Ball]], and in 1922, Alice Busch was selected as that year's Queen of Love and Beauty.Spencer, Thomas M. ''The St. Louis Veiled Prophet Celebration: Power on Parade, 1877–1995,'' U-MO Press, 2000 Both sons joined the family business. Eldest son [[Adolphus Busch III]] became President and CEO of Anheuser-Busch. After his death in 1946, August Jr. became CEO, building the company into the largest brewery in the world. ==Death and legacy== In his later life, Busch suffered from [[heart disease]], [[Edema|dropsy]], and [[gout]]. After being severely ill for several months, he committed [[suicide]] at the age of 68 with a gunshot to the abdomen on February 10, 1934, at the Busch Mansion at [[Grant's Farm]].[http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/metro/article_2efd8b6d-b179-53dc-a6b9-dc9ae1c4e929.html Todd C. Frankel, "For Busch family, woman's death is latest in tragic history" ], ''St. Louis Post-Dispatch,'' December 26, 2010, accessed July 1, 2015 Before shooting himself, August penned a brief note to his family saying, "Goodbye precious mommie and adorable children."{{Cite web|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/metro/a-look-back-shocking-outcome-for-a-busch/article_01648101-f45d-553f-8d85-4fadc616ddbf.html|title=A look back: Shocking outcome for a Busch|last=O'Neil|first=Tim|date=February 14, 2010|website=St. Louis Post Dispatch|publisher=St. Louis Post Dispatch|access-date=August 24, 2016}} The St. Louis County coroner's jury gathered at the Busch mansion and heard Busch's chauffeur testify to the events of August's suicide. A Dr. P.E. Rutledge of Kirkwood also testified that he had given Busch morphine seven hours before the suicide. The coroner's jury ruled August's death a suicide due to long illness. Thousands of people mourned August at the Busch mansion, including senators and brewers. Busch's lawyer, Daniel N. Kirby said during the service, "As worthy son of a noble father, he was as great a leader in saving the industry as his father had been in creating it." Although his parents are buried in a mausoleum at [[Bellefontaine Cemetery]], August wished to be buried at Sunset Burial Park, near [[Grant's Farm]] in [[St. Louis]]. St. Louis police had to keep crowds away from August's grave. In 1947, his widow Alice Busch donated $70,000 to help with the purchase of the [[August A. Busch Memorial Conservation Area]], as a memorial to her husband.{{cite web |title=August A. Busch Memorial Conservation Area |publisher=Missouri Department of Conservation |url=http://mdc4.mdc.mo.gov/applications/moatlas/AreaSummaryPage.aspx?txtAreaID=4901 |accessdate=November 2, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120605141545/http://mdc4.mdc.mo.gov/applications/moatlas/AreaSummaryPage.aspx?txtAreaID=4901 |archive-date=June 5, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} ==See also== *[[Adolph Coors]], brewer in Colorado ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{findagrave|9310}} {{Anheuser-Busch Companies}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Busch, August Anheuser}} [[Category:1865 births]] [[Category:1934 deaths]] [[Category:Businesspeople from St. Louis]] [[Category:American drink industry businesspeople]] [[Category:Suicides by firearm in Missouri]] [[Category:Busch family|August]] [[Category:American people of German descent]] [[Category:Businesspeople who committed suicide]] [[Category:American brewers]]

revision.comment: Merge from [[Plastipedia]] following unopposed 2017 proposal; lack of independent notability; see [[Talk:British Plastics Federation#Proposed merge with Plastipedia]]
revision.text:
The '''British Plastics Federation''' ('''BPF''') is the main trade body for the [[plastic]]s industry in the UK.
==History== It was incorporated on 21 December 1933; the first Chairman was Charles Waghorne of Insulators Limited.<ref>[https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/00282883 Companies House]</ref> It is the longest-established plastics federation in the world.
It was the 1930s that was the decade in which many common plastics were discovered, some in the UK. On 27 March 1933 [[Reginald Gibson]] and [[Eric Fawcett (chemist)|Eric Fawcett]] (with [[Francis Arthur Freeth]] FRS and Sir [[Michael Perrin]]) discovered [[polyethylene]] (polythene) at ICI's [[Winnington Research Laboratory]] at [[Winnington]], [[Cheshire]]; [[John Crawford (chemist)|John Crawford]], at the Explosives group of ICI at [[Ardeer, North Ayrshire]] near [[Stevenston]], produced a commercial synthesis of [[poly(methyl methacrylate)]], also known as Perspex with production beginning in 1934. Polythene is the world's most widespread polymer, and was first produced by ICI from 1939; many plastic bottles are made from [[Low-density polyethylene|LDPE]]. [[Polystyrene]] was invented in Germany in 1937. [[Polytetrafluoroethylene|PTFE]] was discovered in America (New Jersey) in 1938 by [[Roy J. Plunkett]] when at [[DuPont]].
[[Polyethylene terephthalate|PET]] beverage bottles were introduced from 1973. [[Polyether ether ketone|PEEK]] was developed by ICI in 1977. [[High-density polyethylene|HDPE]] water pipes were introduced from 1980. In 1988, a number code for recycling plastics was introduced.
==Structure== It is headquartered in central London. It houses the UK office of the [[PlasticsEurope]] Europe-wide organisation.<ref>[http://www.plasticseurope.org/contact-us.aspx PlasticsEurope]</ref>
===Membership=== Companies in the BPF include - * [[BASF]] UK * [[Polypipe]] * [[Rehau Group]] UK * [[RPC Group]]
==Function== It represents the UK plastics industry. It runs its '''Plastipedia''', a resource on plastics.<ref>[http://www.bpf.co.uk/plastipedia/default.aspx Plastipedia]</ref> In 2009 it launched the [[Plastics 2020 Challenge]].
===Plastipedia=== '''Plastipedia''' is an online [[encyclopedia]] about [[plastic]]s, starting from their birth in 1862 with the invention of [[Parkesine]]; it is hosted and maintained by the BPF. It has a comprehensive list of [[plastic]] [[manufacturing process]]s, and lists the 25 main processing technologies, including detailed animations. It also deals with energy management in the plastic industry and offers a guide to the main standards associated with the plastic industry.
==See also== * [[PET bottle recycling]] * [[Polymer Library]], produced by the Rubber and Plastics Research Association (RAPRA) * [[Society of the Plastics Industry]] (USA)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.bpf.co.uk BPF] * [http://www.eps.co.uk Expanded Polystyrene Group] * [http://www.britishplastics.co.uk Industry news] * [http://www.bpf.co.uk/Plastipedia/default.aspx Plastipedia Website]
{{Plastics}}
[[Category:1933 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Industry trade groups based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Plastics industry]]

{{see also|Double Irish arrangement#Backstop of capital allowances}} '''Capital allowances''' is the practice of allowing a company to get tax relief on tangible capital expenditure by allowing it to be expensed against its annual pre-tax income. Generally, the capital allowances will exist for only specified items of tangible capital expenditure, and the expensing is usually spread over a fixed period of years. The term is used in the UK and in Ireland.
Unusually, the Irish corporate tax system has a [[double Irish arrangement#Backstop of capital allowances|capital allowances for intangible assets]] scheme which allows [[intangible assets]] to be expensed against Irish pre-tax income. It is a key Irish [[base erosion and profit shifting]] (BEPS) tool that U.S. multinationals use to achieve Irish corporate [[Corporation tax in the Republic of Ireland#Effective tax rate (ETR)|effective tax rates]] of <3%, and was used by Apple in Ireland in 2015 ([[leprechaun economics]]).
Capital allowances are in contrast with depreciation, which is not allowed as a deduction for tax purposes, and must be added back to net profit for tax purposes. If capital expenditure does not qualify for a capital allowance, then it means that the business gets no tax relief on such expenditure.
== Categories of asset ==
{{Multiple issues| {{essay-like|date=July 2012}} {{original research|date=July 2012}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Use British English|date=January 2015}}
Capital allowances were introduced in the UK in 1946 <ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.gov.uk/hmrc-internal-manuals/capital-allowances-manual/ca10040|title = HMRC Capital Allowances Manual|date = |accessdate = November 27, 2018 |website = |publisher = HMRC |last = |first = }}</ref> and may be claimed for: * plant and machinery <ref>{{Cite book|title = Capital Allowances Act 2001 Part 2|last = |first = |publisher = |year = |isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref> * business premises renovation <ref>{{Cite book|title = Capital Allowances Act 2001 Part 3A|last = |first = |publisher = |year = |isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref> * flat conversion <ref>{{Cite book|title = Capital Allowances Act 2001 Part 4A|last = |first = |publisher = |year = |isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref> * mineral extraction <ref>{{Cite book|title = Capital Allowances Act 2001 Part 5|last = |first = |publisher = |year = |isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref> * research and development <ref>{{Cite book|title = Capital Allowances Act 2001 Part 6|last = |first = |publisher = |year = |isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref> * know-how <ref>{{Cite book|title = Capital Allowances Act 2001 Part 7|last = |first = |publisher = |year = |isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref> * patents <ref>{{Cite book|title = Capital Allowances Act 2001 Part 8|last = |first = |publisher = |year = |isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref> * dredging <ref>{{Cite book|title = Capital Allowances Act 2001 Part 9|last = |first = |publisher = |year = |isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref> * assured tenancies <ref>{{Cite book|title = Capital Allowances Act 2001 Part 10|last = |first = |publisher = |year = |isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref> Historically, there have also been capital allowances for industrial and agricultural buildings. These have now been phased out, though an allowance may now be claimed for features integral to a building <ref>Finance Act 2012.</ref>
== Plant and machinery == Of these, by far the most important category is plant and machinery.
Neither term is defined in legislation, though guidance is given by HMRC <ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.gov.uk/hmrc-internal-manuals/capital-allowances-manual|title = HMRC Capital Allowances Manual|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
This defined machinery as anything that has a moving part. It does not have to be mechanically powered, so a hand operated device qualifies.
The term "plant" is defined in the court case ''Yarmouth v France'' <ref>CA 1887, 19 QBD 647</ref> which was not a tax case. This held that plant "includes whatever apparatus is used by a businessman for carrying on his business - not his stock in trade, which he buys or makes for sale; but all goods and chattels, fixede or dead, which he keeps for permanent employment in his business". In that case, it was held that his employer's horse was plant.
The scope of exactly what comes within the scope has been the subject of many cases. Among the more important cases, the following have been held to be plant: * a shoe maker's knife that lasted for two years, but not one that lasted for less than two years <ref>Hinton v Maden & Ireland. HL [1959] 38 TC 391.</ref> * a large dry dock, which was held to be equipment rather than premises <ref>CIR v Barclay Curle & Co Ltd. HL [1969] 45 TC 221</ref> * swimming pools at a caravan park <ref>Cooke v Beach Station Caravans Ltd. Ch D [1974] 49 TC 514</ref> * artificial football pitch, held not to be part of the premises <ref>CIR v Anchor International Ltd. CS [2004] 77 TC 38</ref> * grain silos <ref>Schofield v R & H Hall Ltd. CA(NI) [1974] 49 TC 538</ref> * law books owned by a barrister <ref>Munby v Furlong. CA. [1977] 50 TC 491</ref> * gazebo for smokers in the garden of a pub <ref>Mrs C A Andrews v HMRC. FTT [2010] TC 799</ref> * decorative screens in the window of building society branches.<ref>Leeds Permanent Building Society v Proctor. Ch D [1982] 56 TC 293</ref> Where a capital allowances claim has been made on a property a new purchaser can only make another claim valuing the plant and machinery at the same rate as claimed previously. Further claims can be made on a property where it is extended or re-developed but only on those new elements of plant and machinery introduced to the building.
The amount of the allowance depends on what is claimed for. In some cases, the rates are different in the year a business entity made the purchase from those in subsequent years.
A business operator cannot claim capital allowances for things bought or sold: these are claimed as business expenses. If a business asset is bought on a [[hire purchase]] basis, the original cost of the item can be claimed as a capital allowance, but the interest and other charges count as business expenses.
== Types of allowance == The main types of capital allowance are: * annual investment allowance (AIA) introduced from 1 April 2008 <ref>Capital Allowances Act 2001 s38A</ref> * first year allowance (FYA) * writing down allowance (WDA). * balancing allowance (BA). AIA is claimed for plant and machinery, with some exceptions such as for cars. It is fixed amount regardless of the size of the business and so is worth proportionately more for smaller businesses. The amount has varied many times since its introduction. In the 2015 summer Budget it was announced that it would be fixed at £200,000 until 2020.
FYA may be claimed in the tax year in which the asset was acquired.<ref>Capital Allowances Act 2001 s52</ref> It has largely been replaced by AIA. It may still be claimed for certain energy-saving products.
WDA applies to such amounts of allowable expenditure that are not relieved by either AIA or FYA. Broadly it requires all assets to be put into either a general pool, a special pool or a single-asset pool. Assets in the general pool are written down at 18% while those in the special pool are written down at 8%. An asset in a single-asset pool is written down at either 8% or 18% depending on its nature. The advantage is that, on disposal, the whole of the written down value may be offset against taxable profits. The whole balance of a pool may be written off if it falls below £1,000.
BA applies when a business ceases.
==Technical considerations==
Capital allowance reliefs can be set against the client’s taxable profits reducing the amount payable. Companies pay [[Corporation Tax]] at 19% (2018 figure<ref>HMRC website https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/rates-and-allowances-corporation-tax/rates-and-allowances-corporation-tax</ref>), whilst individuals pay tax at 20%, 40% or 45%. Please note as it is an allowance against taxable profit, you have to be a tax payer to benefit, therefore this does not normally apply to property owned in SIPPS or by charities and trusts. Allowances are generated when a business client builds or acquires commercial property. The amount of plant contained within the building or acquired property is the key to maximising the relief.
The claim should be considered as an effective discount and cash contribution to the construction cost or purchase price. The claim provides a tax saving that accrues over time. It is possible to claim allowances on investment properties but plant let in a "dwelling house" is excluded. Blocks of flats, halls of residence etc. will therefore qualify.
For property that is being acquired, the specialist can apportion the purchase price under a recognised HMRC formula, and this is where the inherent property skill can maximise the claim with optimal costing of the plant contained within the property
==See also== * [[Amortization (tax law)]] * [[Depreciation]] * [[Double Irish arrangement#Backstop of capital allowances|Capital allowances for intangible assets (Irish)]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.hmrc.gov.uk HM Revenue & Customs] * [http://www.bytestart.co.uk/content/taxlegal/9_6/capital-allowances.shtml Capital Allowances - A small business guide] * [http://www.eca.gov.uk Enhanced Capital Allowance (ECA) Scheme]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Capital Allowance}} [[Category:Taxation in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Accounting in the United Kingdom]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Carlos Rodriguez-Pastor | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Carlos Tomás Rodríguez-Pastor Persivale | birth_date = {{bya|1959}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | nationality = Peruvian | residence = [[Lima]], Peru | education = | alma mater = [[University of California, Berkeley]]
[[Dartmouth College]] | occupation = businessman | title = chairman and CEO of [[Intercorp]]
managing general partner of [[Nexus Group]]
chairman of [[Interbank]] | term = | predecessor = | successor = | known for = owner of 71% of [[Intergroup Financial]] | boards = [[Royalty Pharma]], [[Casa Andina]], [[Interseguro]], [[Supermercados Peruanos]], [[Inteligo Bank]], [[InRetail]], [[Innova Schools]], and [[NG Restaurants]] | salary = | networth = US$2.6 billion (June 2017){{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/carlos-rodriguez-pastor/ |title=Carlos Rodriguez-Pastor |publisher=Forbes.com |accessdate=14 June 2017}} | spouse = Gabriela Perez Rocchietti | children = 2 | parents = [[Carlos Rodriguez-Pastor Sr.]] | relations = | website = }} '''Carlos Tomás Rodríguez-Pastor Persivale''' (born 1959) is a Peruvian [[billionaire]] businessman, and the owner of 71% of [[Intergroup Financial]], a Peruvian banking and retail group. He is chairman and CEO of [[Intercorp]], managing general partner of [[Nexus Group]], and chairman of [[Interbank]]. ==Early life== Carlos Rodriguez-Pastor was born in 1959.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/photo-essays/2011-08-03/bloomberg-markets-hidden-billionaires |title=Markets: Hidden Billionaires |publisher=Bloomberg |date=3 August 2011 |accessdate=14 June 2017}} In 1968, after a coup, he fled with his family to Ecuador and later California. His father [[Carlos Rodriguez-Pastor Sr.]] was Peru's Minister of Economy from 1982 to 1984. In 1994, his father bought [[Banco Internacional del Peru]], but died the following year. He was educated at the [[Immaculate Heart College]] in Lima, Peru. In 1983 he received a bachelor's degree in Social Sciences from the [[University of California, Berkeley]], and in 1988, an MBA from [[Dartmouth College]].{{cite web|url=https://www.weforum.org/people/carlos-rodriguez-pastor/ |title=Carlos Rodriguez-Pastor | World Economic Forum |website=Weforum.org |date= |accessdate=14 June 2017}} ==Career== From 1990-93, he was a vice-president at [[Citibank]], New York, and from 1993-95, a managing director at [[Banco Santander]], New York. Since 1995, he has been chairman and CEO of [[Intercorp]]; managing general partner of [[Nexus Group]]; chairman of [[Interbank]], and a director of [[Royalty Pharma]], [[Casa Andina]], [[Interseguro]], [[Supermercados Peruanos]], [[Inteligo Bank]], [[InRetail]], [[Innova Schools]], and [[NG Restaurants]]. Rodriguez-Pastor did not want anyone to know how rich he is, "I don't see what the big deal is". ==Personal life== He is married to Gabriela Perez Rocchietti, they have two children, and live in [[Lima]], Peru. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rodriguez-Pastor, Carlos}} [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Lima]] [[Category:Peruvian businesspeople]] [[Category:Peruvian billionaires]] {{Peru-business-bio-stub}}

'''Chad Hamre''' is the CEO and co-founder of [[Ethical Ocean]]- a social business incorporated federally in Canada in 2008. Hamre was born and raised in [[Saskatoon]], [[Saskatchewan]]. He holds a [[master's degree]] in Development Management from the [[London School of Economics]] and a [[bachelor's degree]] in Mechanical Engineering from the [[University of Saskatchewan]]. In 2005, he was awarded the Student Gold Medal<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.engineerscanada.ca/e/files/goldmedstud_05.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706180302/http://www.engineerscanada.ca/e/files/goldmedstud_05.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-06 |df= }}</ref> by [[Engineers Canada]]. In 2008, he was awarded the Outstanding Young Alumni Award<ref>https://www.usask.ca/alumni/alumni_association/alumni_awards/alumni_recipients/Past%20Recipients.php</ref> by the University of Saskatchewan Alumni Association.
==References== <references/>

revision.text:
'''Chemical plant cost indexes''' are [[dimensionless number]]s employed to updating [[capital cost]] required to erect a [[chemical plant]] from a past date to a later time, following changes in the value of money due to [[inflation]] and deflation. Since, at any given time, the number of chemical plants is insufficient to use in a preliminary or predesign estimate, cost indexes are handy for a series of management purposes, like long-range planning, budgeting and escalating or de-escalating contract costs.<ref>Pintelon, L. & Puyvelde, F. V., 1997. Estimating Plant Construction Costs. Chemical Engineering, August, pp. 98-104</ref>
A cost index is the ratio of the actual price in a time period compared to that in a selected base period (a defined point in time or the average price in a certain year), multiplied by 100. Raw materials, products and energy prices, labor and construction costs change at different rates, and plant construction cost indexes are actually a composite, able to compare generic chemical plants capital costs.
==Calculations methods==
Although the available indexes are compiled in several ways, they are defined to encompass a specific set of conditions and items. Prices for these items can be obtained either through company’s purchasing department data or through published indexes, like those published by the [[Bureau of Labor Statistics]] (BLS).<ref>Humphreys, K. K., 2005. Project and Cost Engineers' Handbook. 4th ed. s.l.:Marcel Dekker</ref> Both the CE and the IC indexes, from Chemical Engineering and Intratec, respectively, employs BLS’ data.
The weighting of such factors, which is defined by the realized degree of importance of each component in the specific index (or sub-index), aims to represent the costs variations typically found for chemical plants.
==Using a cost index==
To update an item cost (equipment, projects) from period A to period B, is necessary to multiply period A’s cost by the ratio of period B’s index over period A’s index, according to the following equation:
<math>\text{Cost at B} = \text{Cost at A}\cdot \frac{\text{index at B }}{\text{index at A }}</math>
As a rule-of-thumb, cost indexes permit fairly accurate estimates for cost escalation if the difference between period A and period B is less than 10 years. Differences between the actual equipment and labor prices and those predicted by the index tend to grow over the years, surpassing the typical error verified in budget-level estimates.<ref>Peters, M., Timmerhaus, K. & West, R., 2004. Plant Design and Economics for Chemical Engineers. 5th ed. s.l.:McGraw-Hill</ref><ref>Vatavuk, W. M., 2002. Updating the CE Plant Cost Index. Chemical Engineering, January, pp. 62-70</ref>
==Cost indexes in engineering==
The selection of the proper index to use depends on the industry in which it is applied. For example, while CE, M&S or IC Index are typically employed for chemical process industries, the ENR ([[Engineering News-Record]]) construction index is used for general industrial construction and takes in account the prices for fixed amounts of structural steel, cement, lumber and labor.
The majority of cost indexes demonstrate a time lag, due to data collection and its compilation for publishing. As stated before, some indexes use information published by other organizations and a delay in data may be verified (like those provide by the BLS). Exceptions to this are the ENR construction and the IC indexes, which present relatively current values.
The main indexes available for process industries include:
* '''Chemical Engineering Index, CE''': composed of 4 major components – equipment, construction labor, buildings, and engineering and supervision – the index is employed primary as a process plant construction index, was established using a base period of 1957-1959 as 100. The CE Index is updated monthly and it lags in time by about 3 months. The CE Index was revised in 1982, to account for changes in labor productivity and, again, in 2002.<ref>Couper, J. R., 2003. Process Engineering Economics. s.l.:Marcel Dekker</ref> Published in each issue of Chemical Engineering.<ref>Albright, L.. 2008. Albright's Chemical Engineering Handbook. s.l.:CRC-Press</ref><ref>http://www.chemengonline.com/pci/</ref> * '''Marshall and Swift Cost Index, M&S''' (originally known as Marshall and Stevens Index): a composite of two major components - process-industry equipment average and all-industry equipment average - was established in 1926 with a value of 100. Some industries considered in the process-industry equipment average are chemicals, petroleum products, rubber and paper. The all-industry average encompasses 47 different types of industrial, commercial and housing equipment. Published monthly in each issue of Chemical Engineering until April 2012.<ref>http://www.equipment-cost-index.com/</ref> * '''Intratec Chemical Plant Construction Index, IC''': a process plant construction index developed by Intratec, a chemical consulting company. Although cost indexes do not usually forecast future escalation, the IC Index stands out for presenting a smaller delay between release date and index date, besides a 12 months forecast.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.slideshare.net/intratec/intratec-chemical-plant-construction-index |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120929012909/http://www.slideshare.net/intratec/intratec-chemical-plant-construction-index |archivedate=2012-09-29 |df= }}</ref> On the other hand, the index is only available from January 2000 (with a value of 100). A sample is available at Intratec’s website.<ref>http://www.intratec.us/ic</ref> * '''Nelson-Farrar Indexes, NF''' (originally known as the Nelson Refinery Construction Indexes): established in 1946 with a value of 100, the index is more suitable for petroleum or petrochemical business. Published once a month in the Oil and Gas Journal.
==Cost Indexes for different locations== The standard indexes available are usually restricted to a particular region, as in the case of '''NF Index''', which is accurate only to the region of the US Gulf coast (USGC). Likewise most of the data available for plant and equipment costs are mostly either in # '''US Gulf Coast Basis (USGC)''' # '''Northwest Europe Basis (NWE)''' Hence the Index values cannot be used to get accurate results in other regions of the world. This variation might be due various factors such as * Cost and availability of materials * Cost and availability of labor * Cost of transportation of equipment and labor * Import duties and local taxes * Currency exchange rates Of all these factors currency exchange rates is said to have the greatest impact in the variation of results.
Cost indexes for international locations is published in ''"Process Engineering"'' journal as well as in the ''"International Journal of Production Economics"'' (formerly ''"Engineering Costs and Production Economics"''). As of 2012 "''Process Engineering"'' has not been publishing new indexes viewable by full access from EbscoHost. They mentioned in May/June 2012 that their analyst had fallen sick.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Plant Cost Indices|last = |first = |date = May 2012|journal = Process Engineering|doi = |pmid = |volume = 93|issue = 3|page = 62}}</ref>
==Location Factor== In order to be able to use the available standard indexes to locations where index data is not available we have to incorporate a new term called the '''Location Factor (LF) '''to the standard index value. It is a dimensionless value for a particular location relative to either of the above-mentioned basis.
'''''Cost in A = Cost in USGC x LF(A)'''''
where '''A''' is the location for which cost is being evaluated and '''LF(A)''' is the location factor for the location A relative to USGC
Location factors are greatly influenced by currency exchange rates due to their significant effect on Index value and hence vary drastically with time. Over the past couple of decades the location factors for various locations are trending close to the value 1. However location factor for a particular region within a country can be easily determined by adding 10% to the index of the reference location for every 1000 miles. The reference location is usually a major industrial location closest to the location where the index is being determined. Location factors for various locations have been published and updated in various journals as in Aspen Richardson's ''"International Construction Cost Factor Location Manual (2003)".''
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Chemical process engineering]] [[Category:Chemical industry]] [[Category:Manufacturing plants]]

{{Infobox company | name = Cubist Pharmaceuticals, INC | logo = Cubist Pharmaceuticals Logo.svg | logo_size = 228px | traded_as = Formerly {{NASDAQ|CBST}} | type = Subsidiary (formerly: [[Public]]) | key_people = [[Robert J. Perez]], President, CEO; | industry = [[Pharmaceuticals]] (Biopharmaceuticals & Biotherapeutics) | products = [http://www.cubist.com/products/ Product Pipeline] | revenue = {{profit}} $926.4 million [[United States dollar|USD]] (2012) | homepage = [http://www.cubist.com/ www.cubist.com] | foundation = 1992 | defunct = 2015 | parent = [[Merck & Co.]] | location = [[Lexington, Massachusetts]] }}
'''Cubist Pharmaceuticals''' was a U.S. [[biopharmaceutical]] company with activities spanning from research and development to commercialization of pharmaceutical products. Its main products target pathogens like [[Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus|MRSA]].
Cubist was one of the few firms that continued to research in antibiotics while larger pharmaceutical companies have abandoned such research.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.fiercebiotechresearch.com/story/cubist-exec-challenges-mount-antibiotics-discovery/2014-08-26| title= Cubist exec: Challenges mount in antibiotics discovery| last= Mullin| first=Emily| date=26 Aug 2014| accessdate= 23 Nov 2014| website= Fiercebiotechresearch.com}}</ref> The company employs 638 people, with 370 in their headquarters in Lexington, MA.<ref>{{cite web |title= Cubist Pharmaceuticals Inc. homesite | work=2009 Annual Report|url=http://www.snl.com/irweblinkx/file.aspx?FID=1500026840&IID=4093793 |accessdate=20 May 2011 }}</ref> As of 2011, the company’s headquarters are under expansion and is expected to occupy {{convert|373,000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} in Lexington, MA. On 8 December 2014, [[Merck & Co.]] acquired Cubist for $102 per share in cash ($8.4 billion) as entree to the market for drugs that can combat [[super bug (bacteria)|superbugs]].<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/12/09/us-cubist-pharma-m-a-merck-idUSKBN0JM19X20141209 Merck to take on superbugs with Cubist Pharma buy]. [[Reuters]], 9 December 2014</ref>
==History== Cubist was founded in May 1992 by John K. Clarke, [[Paul Schimmel|Paul R. Schimmel, Ph.D.]] and [[Barry Bloom]], Ph.D, all of whom were also directors.<ref>{{cite web | title=SEC Form S3 Cubist Pharmaceuticals, Inc. | date=March 8, 2000 | url=http://www.nasdaq.com/markets/spos/filing.ashx?filingid=1123315}}</ref> Cubist appeared on Fortune 2010’s List of fastest growing companies, and was named to the 2010 Deloitte Technology Fast 500.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortunefastestgrowing/2010/|title=100 FASTEST-GROWING COMPANIES|date=2010|accessdate=28 May 2011|work=CNN}}</ref> In 2006 it had the [[List of biotechnology companies|19th highest sales]] among American based biotechnology companies.
In 2011, the company acquired Adolor, maker of a drug for treatment of [[constipation]].<ref name=apcubist2012/>
Cubist had an ambitious growth plan laid out for the 2012-2017 quinquennium. Under this plan, the company was expected to reach 2B dollars in sales and have 4 new drugs in late stage development by 2017. As a part of this plan, sales of its flagship drug Cubicin were expected to grow to more than 1B dollars per year.
In July 2013, Cubist Pharmaceuticals agreed to purchase [[Trius Therapeutics]] and [[Optimer Pharmaceuticals]] for around $1.6 billion.<ref>{{cite news| url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/07/31/us-cubist-deal-idUSBRE96T1BI20130731| title= Cubist to pay up to $1.6 billion for two antibiotics makers | author= Vrinda Manocha and Zeba Siddiqui | publisher=Reuters | date=30 July 2013}}</ref>
In 2014, succeeding [[Michael Bonney]] as President, Robert J. Perez, was announced to take leadership on January 1, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2014/10/20/new-cubist-pharmaceuticals-chief-executive-will-robert-perez/wf8FbqJsIQSS4HxQQmCzVM/story.html| title=New Cubist Pharmaceuticals chief executive will be Robert J. Perez | date= 20 Oct 2014| accessdate= 23 Nov 2014| last=Weisman| first=Robert| website=www.BostonGlobe.com}}</ref> In January 2015 Cubist Pharmaceuticals became a wholly owned subsidiary of Merck & Co.
==Products== The company markets Cubicin ([[daptomycin]]) for injection, the first antibiotic in a class of anti-infectives called [[lipopeptides]]. In 2011, Cubist settled a patent litigation with [[Teva Pharmaceutical Industries]] regarding Cubicin.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-04-04/cubist-licenses-cubicin-antibiotic-to-teva-in-patent-suit-settlement.html|title=Cubist Settles Teva Patent Litigation on Antibiotic Cubicin|date=2011-04-05|accessdate=28 May 2011|work=Bloomberg}}</ref> In April 2011 it reached a deal with Optimer Pharmaceuticals in which its class of bacterium fighting drugs will be co marketed with Optimer's Fidaxomicin/Dificid (for $15 million per year). Optimer chose Cubist because according to its CEO, "Cubist has a proven track record and well established relations with all stakeholders involved in the antibiotics space".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-04-06/optimer-to-co-market-dificid-drug-with-cubist-pharmaceuticals.html|title=Optimer to Market Dificid Drug With Cubist Pharmaceuticals|date=2011-04-06 | work=Bloomberg}}</ref>
In 2011, its product pipeline focused on gram-negative bacterial infections,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/boston/news/2011/12/13/cubist-advances-antibiotic-candidate.html|title=Cubist advances antibiotic for Gram-negative bacteria|last=Donnelly|first=Julie M.|date=13 December 2011|website=www.bizjournals.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-31}}</ref> ''Clostridium difficile''-associated diarrhea,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/boston/news/2011/04/06/cubist-collaboration-on-drug-could.html|title=Cubist - Optimer diarrhea drug could net $47M|last=Brown|first=Rodney H.|date=6 April 2011|website=www.bizjournals.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-31}}</ref> and respiratory syncytial virus.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.genomeweb.com/rnai/alnylam-loses-cubist-rsv-partner-stays-focused-attr-programs|title=Alnylam Loses Cubist as RSV Partner, Stays Focused on ATTR Programs|work=GenomeWeb|access-date=2017-10-31|language=en}}</ref>
[[Tedizolid]] was approved by the US [[Food and Drug Administration]] on June 20, 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pharmacytimes.com/publications/health-system-edition/2014/september2014/sivextro-by-cubist-pharmaceuticals|title=Sivextro by Cubist Pharmaceuticals|website=www.pharmacytimes.com|access-date=2017-10-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fiercebiotech.com/biotech/cubist-announces-fda-acceptance-of-tedizolid-new-drug-application-priority-review|title=Cubist Announces FDA Acceptance of Tedizolid New Drug Application with Priority Review {{!}} FierceBiotech|website=www.fiercebiotech.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-31}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2|refs=
<ref name=apcubist2012>{{Citation |author=Associated Press |publication-date=19 Jan 2012 |title=Cubist Profit Down 53% |periodical=[[Drug Discovery & Development]] |publisher=[[Advantage Business Media]] |accessdate=22 Jan 2012 |url=http://www.dddmag.com/news-Cubist-Profit-Down-53-12012.aspx }}</ref>
}}
==External links== *Kennedy, Val Brickates, [http://www.marketwatch.com/story/nothing-bugs-cubist-ceo-michael-bonney-2012-01-17 "Nothing bugs Cubist CEO Michael Bonney"], ''MarketWatch'', January 17, 2012.

{{Infobox person | name = | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1844|08|28|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Newport, Rhode Island]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1915|04|04|1844|08|28|df=yes}} | death_place = [[New Rochelle, New York]], U.S. | death_cause = | resting_place = | residence = | education = | alma_mater = [[United States Military Academy]]
[[Trinity College, Cambridge]]
[[Columbia Law School]] | employer = | occupation = | spouse = {{marriage|[[Eleanora Iselin Kane|Eleanora Iselin]]
|1872|1915|reason=his death}} | children = | parents = DeLancey Kane
Louisa Dorothea Langdon | relations = [[Woodbury Kane]] (brother)
[[S. Nicholson Kane]] (brother)
[[Sybil Kent Kane]] (sister) }} '''DeLancey Astor Kane''' (August 28, 1844 – April 4, 1915) was an American soldier and horseman who was prominent in New York Society during the [[Gilded Age]]. He was called the "father of coaching in the United States."{{cite book|title=Harness|date=1915|publisher=Trade News Publishing Company|page=2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zpY7AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PR2|accessdate=2 March 2018|language=en}} == Early life == Kane was born on August 28, 1844 in [[Newport, Rhode Island]]. He was the second of eight children born to Oliver DeLancey Kane (1816–1874) and Louisa Dorothea ([[née]] Langdon) Kane (1821–1894). His brothers were Walter Langdon, John Innes Kane, [[Woodbury Kane]],{{cite news|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1905/12/06/101424490.pdf |title=Capt Woodbury Kane dies of sudden heart attack|date=6 December 1905|work=The New York Times|pages=11|accessdate=13 June 2009 | format=PDF}} [[S. Nicholson Kane]]. His sisters were Louisa Langdon Kane,{{cite news|title=LOUISE L. KANE DIES AFTER BRIEF ILLNESS; Granddaughter of the First John Jacob Astor Was a Benefactor of Artists. DID QUIET PHILANTHROPY Gave Much Time to Welfare Work, Aiding Bellevue Particularly -Family Socially Prominent.|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1927/06/02/104072540.pdf |accessdate=2 March 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2 June 1927}} Emily Astor Kane (who married Augustus Jay and was the mother of [[Peter Augustus Jay (diplomat)|Peter Augustus Jay]]), and [[Sybil Kent Kane]].{{cite news|title=MRS. AUGUSTUS JAY DIES IN 79TH YEAR; Widow of Diplomat Whose Ancestor, John Jay, Was First Chief Justice of U. S. LONG A SOCIETY LEADER Descended From Gov. Langdon of New Hampshire, Revolutionary Soldier, and John Jacob Astor.|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1932/12/15/100883597.pdf |accessdate=2 March 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=15 December 1932}}{{cite book|title=The Successful American, Vol 1, Part 1|date=1899|publisher=Press Biographical Company|page=156|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NmZMAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA156|accessdate=2 March 2018|language=en}} He was the grandson of Walter Langdon and Dorothea (née Astor) Langdon and the great-grandson of [[John Jacob Astor]]. He was a cousin of Lt. Col. [[John Jacob Astor IV]]. His paternal lineage descended from John O'Kane who emigrated to the country in 1752 from [[County Londonderry]] and [[Antrim, Ireland]]. During the [[American Revolutionary War]], O'Kane (who dropped the "'O" once in America) was living at Sharyvogne, his estate in [[Dutchess County, New York|Dutchess County]], which was confiscated after the War due to his [[Loyalist (American Revolution)|Loyalist]] times. His eldest son, John Jr., stayed and became one of the most prominent merchants in New York. The family lived at "Beach Cliffe", designed by [[Detlef Lienau]], which was one the earliest Newport cottages "to attain a sort of [[Beaux-Arts architecture|Beaux-Arts]] purity."{{cite book|last1=Yarnall|first1=James L.|title=Newport Through Its Architecture: A History of Styles from Postmedieval to Postmodern|date=2005|publisher=UPNE|isbn=9781584654919|page=123|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9sCQ8ixFnXwC&pg=PA123|accessdate=2 March 2018|language=en}}{{refn|group=lower-alpha|"Beach Cliffe", built in 1852, was located on Bath Road at Rhode Island Avenue in Newport. It was torn down in 1939.}} Kane graduated from the [[United States Military Academy]] at [[West Point, New York]] in 1868. Following his service in the [[U.S. Army]], he studied at [[Trinity College, Cambridge]] in [[England]] and in 1873, graduated from [[Columbia Law School]]. ==Career== Kane, who inherited $10,000,000 from his mother's family,{{cite book|title=American Millionaires: The Tribune's List of Persons Reputed to Worth a Million Or More. Lines of Business in which the Fortunes Were Made|date=1892|publisher=Tribune Association|page=71|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wJFOAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA71|accessdate=2 March 2018|language=en}} was a [[Lieutenant (United States)|Lieutenant]] in the First Cavalry, U.S.A. from 1868 to 1870 when he retired as a [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]], a title by which he was known for most of his life. In 1876, Kane founded, with Col. William Jay,{{cite book|last1=Montgomery|first1=Maureen E.|title=Displaying Women: Spectacles of Leisure in Edith Wharton's New York|date=2016|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781134952793|page=110|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xm4WDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT110|accessdate=2 March 2018|language=en}} [[Coaching Club (of New York)|The Coaching Club]] of New York devoted to the coaching of horses which he picked up after his time spent in England.{{cite journal|last1=Wheeling|first1=Ken|title=The Tally-Ho: a Road Coach|journal=The Carriage Journal|date=1 October 2009|volume=Vol 47 No 4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c9BEDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA266|accessdate=2 March 2018|publisher=Carriage Assoc. of America|language=en}}{{cite book|last1=Thorn|first1=John|title=Base Ball: A Journal of the Early Game|date=2016|publisher=McFarland|isbn=9781476621395|page=29|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nBWRDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT29|accessdate=2 March 2018|language=en}} His [[stagecoach]], "Tally-ho" was the first private stagecoach for pleasure riding in the [[United States]]. ===Society life=== [[File:KaneDL.JPG|thumb|right|Kane's country estate, "The Paddocks" in [[New Rochelle, NY]]]] In 1892, both Kane and his wife Eleanora were included in [[Ward McAllister]]'s [[Ward McAllister#"The Four Hundred"|"Four Hundred"]], purported to be an index of New York's best families, published in ''[[The New York Times]]''.{{cite news|last1=McAllister|first1=Ward|title=THE ONLY FOUR HUNDRED {{!}} WARD M'ALLISTER GIVES OUT THE OFFICIAL LIST. HERE ARE THE NAMES, DON'T YOU KNOW, ON THE AUTHORITY OF THEIR GREAT LEADER, YOU UNDER- STAND, AND THEREFORE GENUINE, YOU SEE.|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1892/02/16/108210917.pdf|accessdate=26 March 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=16 February 1892|language=en}}{{cite book|last1=Patterson|first1=Jerry E.|title=The First Four Hundred: Mrs. Astor's New York in the Gilded Age|date=2000|publisher=[[Random House]]|isbn=9780847822089|page=218|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZLwMAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=2 March 2018|language=en}} Conveniently, 400 was the number of people that could fit into [[Mrs. Astor]]'s ballroom.{{cite book|last1=Keister|first1=Lisa A.|title=Getting Rich: America's New Rich and How They Got That Way|date=2005|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=9780521536677|page=36|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5dAtJf1hmAUC&pg=PA36|accessdate=20 October 2017|language=en}}{{cite book|last1=Birmingham|first1=Stephen|title=Life at the Dakota: New York's Most Unusual Address|date=2015|publisher=Open Road Media|isbn=9781504026314|page=18|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MtPSCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT18|accessdate=2 March 2018|language=en}} He was a member of the [[Union Club of the City of New York|Union Club]], [[Metropolitan Club]], the [[Knickerbocker Club]], Country Club, the [[Coaching Club (of New York)|Coaching Club]], the [[New York Yacht Club]] and the [[Larchmont Yacht Club]]s.{{cite book|title=Club Men of New York: Full Membership of the Leading Clubs, Societies, College Alumni Associations, Etc., of Greater New York. Occupations, Business and Home Address. Historical Sketches of All Prominent New York Organizations. Principal Clubs, with Addresses, in the One Hundred Largest Cities of the United States|date=1893|publisher=Republic Press|page=262|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mb8OAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=2 March 2018|language=en}} His wife's father built them a county estate, known as "The Paddocks" in [[Davenport Neck]], [[New Rochelle, New York|New Rochelle]]. The estate had a panoramic view of the [[Long Island Sound]] and [[Fort Slocum]]. ==Personal life== In 1872, Kane was married to [[Eleanora Iselin Kane|Eleanora Iselin]] (1849–1938),{{cite news|title=MRS. DELANCEY A. KANE; Member of Old New York Family Dies in Westchester at 89|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1938/10/23/98866587.pdf |accessdate=2 March 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=23 October 1938}} the daughter of [[Adrian Georg Iselin]], a prominent New York merchant and banker. Eleanora was also the sister of [[Columbus Iselin|Columbus]] and [[Charles Oliver Iselin|Charles Iselin]]. In 1901, Kane and his wife purchased the former home of Arthur Astor Carey{{refn|group=lower-alpha|Arthur Astor Carey (1857–1923), was also a member of the [[Astor family]] through his mother, Mary Alida Astor (1826–1881), the daughter of [[William Backhouse Astor Sr.]]}} in Newport for $100,000 where he became a permanent resident.{{cite news|title=Col. Kane to Live in Newport.|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1901/01/02/118459339.pdf |accessdate=2 March 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 2, 1901}} Together, they were the parents of one child: * DeLancey Iselin Kane (1877–1940),{{cite news|title=DELANCEY ISELIN KANE; Great-Grandson of the First John Jacob Astor Dies, 62|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1940/08/01/112750805.pdf |work=[[The New York Times]]|date=1 August 1940}} who was painted by [[Thomas Wilmer Dewing]] in 1887.{{cite book|last1=Gallati|first1=Barbara Dayer|last2=Forum|first2=Bucerius Kunst|title=High Society: American Portraits of the Gilded Age|date=2008|publisher=Hirmer|pages=83, 84, 86|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ItrqAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=2 March 2018|language=en}}{{cite book|last1=Merrill|first1=Linda|last2=Whistler|first2=James McNeill|title=After Whistler: The Artist and His Influence on American Painting|date=2003|publisher=[[Yale University Press]]|isbn=0300101252|page=174|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zQBQaaQVbz0C&pg=PA174|accessdate=2 March 2018|language=en}} Kane died of [[pneumonia]] on April 4, 1915 at the Kane estate in [[Davenport Neck]] in [[New Rochelle, New York]].{{cite news|title=COL. DE LANCEY KANE DIES OF PNEUMONIA; Noted Horseman and Astor's Great-Grandson Initiated Coaching in America. LONG A SOCIAL LEADER Graduate of West Point Who Inherited $10,000,000 Served in the Cavalry in Our Army. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1915/04/05/100148086.pdf |accessdate=2 March 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=5 April 1915}}{{refn|group=lower-alpha|The Paddocks later became the Colony Club and was torn down in the 1980s to become the current Surf Club.{{cite book|last1=Davis|first1=Barbara|title=New Rochelle|date=2012|publisher=[[Arcadia Publishing]]|isbn=9780738592831|page=9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v5o78L0q_wQC&pg=PA9|accessdate=2 March 2018|language=en}}}} ==References== ;Notes {{Reflist|group=lower-alpha}} ;Sources {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{findagrave|80380186}} * [http://collections.mcny.org/C.aspx?VP3=SearchResult&VBID=24UAYWL80YVE0 Painting of DeLancey Iselin Kane dressed in a sailor suite] by [[Thomas Wilmer Dewing]] in 1887 at the [[Museum of the City of New York]] * [http://collections.mcny.org/Collection/Eleanora-Iselin-Kane-(Mrs.-DeLancey-Astor-Kane)-2F3XC58PBLNW.html Painting of Eleanora Iselin Kane (Mrs. DeLancey Astor Kane)] by [[Thomas Wilmer Dewing]] in 1888 at the [[Museum of the City of New York]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Kane, DeLancey Astor}} [[Category:1844 births]] [[Category:1915 deaths]] [[Category:Astor family|DeLancey Astor Kane]] [[Category:United States Military Academy alumni]] [[Category:Alumni of Trinity College, Cambridge]] [[Category:Columbia Law School alumni]] [[Category:Military personnel from New Rochelle, New York]] [[Category:People included in New York Society's Four Hundred]]

revision.comment: Infobox company: fix bad parameter names
revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Duck Commander, Inc. | logo = [[File:Duck Commander logo.png|150px|Duck Commander Logo since 2000]] | vector_logo = | caption = Duck Commander logo | type = Private | foundation = 1972 | location = [[West Monroe, Louisiana|West Monroe]], [[Louisiana]], [[United States]] | key_people = [[Phil Robertson]] (Founder & President)
[[Willie Robertson]] (CEO)
[[Jase Robertson]] (COO)
Kay Robertson (Vice President) | industry = [[Hunting]]
[[Apparel]] | owners = Willie Robertson, Jase Robertson, Phil Robertson | products = [[Duck call]]s
[[Contact call|Buck calls]] and accessories | revenue = $40 million (2012){{Citation needed|date=July 2017}} | operating_income = $20 million (2012){{Citation needed|date=July 2017}} | owner = Willie Robertson, Jase Robertson, Phil Robertson, Jep Robertson | num_employees = 15 (2011)
75 (2012) | subsid = [[Duck Dynasty]]
Buck Commander
Strut Commander
Fin Commander | homepage = http://duckcommander.com/}} '''Duck Commander''' is both the [[brand]] of a [[duck call]] and the name of the company in [[West Monroe, Louisiana]], [[United States]]. The company manufactures these calls and other duck-hunting merchandise,{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-277436104.html |title=Duck Commander |journal=Shooting Industry Magazine |date=January 1, 2012 |last= Smith |first= Roxanne}} as well as deer-hunting merchandise under the '''Buck Commander''' brand. [[Phil Robertson]], a [[American football|football]] [[quarterback]] at [[Louisiana Tech University]], founded the company. He began his business in a dilapidated boat, where he spent 25 years making duck calls from Louisiana cedar trees.{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/redneck-millionaires-built-duck-dynasty-duck-call-business/story?id=15961955#.T4H3ytl5nXo |title='Redneck' Millionaires Built 'Duck Dynasty' in Duck Call Business |work=ABC News |date=March 20, 2012 |accessdate=April 8, 2012 |first1=Ryan |last1=Owens |first2=Jim |last2=Scholz }} Robertson's third son, [[Willie Robertson]], currently serves as the company's [[chief executive officer]] and has expanded it into a multimillion-dollar enterprise.{{cite web |url =http://duckcommander.com/meet-the-family/willie-robertson |title =Willie Robertson |website =Duck Commander |accessdate =December 26, 2013 }} The Robertson family and business are the subjects of ''[[Duck Dynasty]]'', a [[reality television]] series on [[A&E (TV channel)|A&E]]. Before that, they were featured in the ''Duck Commander'' television show on the [[Outdoor Channel]].{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/18/arts/mar-19-24.html |title=The Week Ahead, Mar. 19–24 |work=The New York Times |date=March 16, 2012 |accessdate=December 7, 2012}} ==Sports and sponsorships== ===Duck Commander 500=== {{main|Duck Commander 500}} In 2014, Duck Commander served as the title sponsor of the [[Duck Commander 500]], a [[NASCAR]] [[Sprint Cup Series]] stock car race held at [[Texas Motor Speedway]] in [[Fort Worth]], [[Texas]] which had been previously sponsored by [[Samsung]], [[DirecTV]], [[Radio Shack]], [[National Rifle Association]], and others.{{cite news|last=Owens|first=Jeff|title=Duck Dynasty stars to sponsor NASCAR race at Texas|work=Sporting News|date=February 6, 2014|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/nascar/story/2014-02-06/duck-dynasty-texas-motor-speedway-sponsor-race-phil-robertson-controversy-ae-suspension|accessdate=February 6, 2014}} It was replaced by [[O'Reilly Automotive|O'Reilly Auto Parts]] in 2017.{{cite web |url=http://www.texasmotorspeedway.com/news/daily-news/news-releases/2016/05/16/o'reilly-auto-parts-signs-multi-year-entitlement-deal-for-annual-spring-nascar-sprint-cup-race |publisher=Texas Motor Speedway |title=O'Reilly Auto Parts Signs Multi-year Entitlement Deal for Annual Spring NASCAR Sprint Cup Race |date=2016-05-16 |accessdate=2016-05-16}} ===Duck Commander Independence Bowl=== {{main|Independence Bowl}} Duck Commander also purchased in 2014 the naming rights for college football's [[Independence Bowl]], held each year in [[Shreveport]], Louisiana. ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 2009–2010 | ''Duck Commander'' | Aired on [[Outdoor Channel]]https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1477772/combined |- | 2011 | ''Presents: Buck Commander Protected by [[Under Armour]]'' | ''Duck Commander'' spin-off |- | 2012–2017 | ''[[Duck Dynasty]]'' | The hit [[A&E (TV channel)|A&E]] show |- | 2014 | ''Duck Commander: Before the Dynasty'' | Episodes air on A&E, consisting of clips from the original series interspersed with modern-day commentary from members of the Robertson family. Aired between Seasons 6 and 7 of ''Duck Dynasty''. |- | 2016–present | ''Jep & Jessica: Growing the Dynasty'' | Follows Jep Robertson, Phil's youngest son, and his wife Jessica as they adopt a baby boy into their family. |- | 2016–present | ''Going Si-ral'' | Follows [[Si Robertson]], Phil's brother, as he explores various quirks of the Internet. |} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.duckcommander.com Official website] {{Duck Commander}} [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1972]] [[Category:Privately held companies based in Louisiana]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies based in Louisiana]] [[Category:Sporting goods manufacturers of the United States]] [[Category:Robertson family]] [[Category:1972 establishments in Louisiana]] {{US-manufacturing-company-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Use British English|date=February 2017}} [[File:Centre for Regenerative Medicine.jpg|thumb|The [[Scottish Centre for Regenerative Medicine]], at [[Little France]] in Edinburgh, was opened in May 2012; it is home to the Institute for Stem Cell Research, part of the Edinburgh Science Triangle.]] The '''Edinburgh Science Triangle''' ('''EST''') is a multi-disciplinary partnership between universities, research institutes, the [[Scottish National Health Service|National Health Service]], science parks, the national economic development agency [[Scottish Enterprise]], and [[Scottish Government|central]] and [[Local government in Scotland|local government]] in Edinburgh and neighbouring council areas. The three points of the "triangle" are [[Livingston, Scotland|Livingston]] in [[West Lothian]], [[Musselburgh]] in [[East Lothian]], and the [[Easter Bush campus]] in [[Midlothian]].
The collaborative project aims to attract new indigenous and [[inward investment]], and to build a professional scientific community based on academic research and commercial enterprises. The target sectors for the project are the [[life sciences]], [[Informatics (academic field)|informatics]], [[Microelectronics|micro-]] and [[optoelectronics]] and [[Energy industry|energy]].
The Edinburgh Science Triangle was launched by [[Jim Wallace]], the [[Deputy First Minister of Scotland|Deputy First Minister]], in September 2004,<ref name=Launch>{{cite press release|title=Launch of Edinburgh Science Triangle|archiveurl=https://wayback.archive-it.org/3011/20130204024403/http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2004/09/30094733 |archivedate=4 February 2013|url=http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2004/09/30094733|publisher=Scottish Government|date=30 September 2004}}</ref> at the [[Roslin BioCentre]] in [[Midlothian]]. It is a member of Edinburgh's Local Investment Partnership, which includes the [[City of Edinburgh Council]], Edinburgh Chamber of Commerce, [[Scottish Development International]] and Scottish Enterprise. Scottish Development International promotes the Edinburgh Science Triangle abroad.
Funding to promote and support the Edinburgh Science Triangle comes from Scottish Enterprise, the [[European Regional Development Fund]], the City of Edinburgh, [[Midlothian Council|Midlothian]] and [[West Lothian Council|West Lothian]] councils, and the participating science parks.<ref name=Launch />
==Participants==
===Easter Bush Campus=== [[File:DickVetSchool.jpg|thumb|In September 2011 the [[Dick Vet]] relocated from Summerhall, in Edinburgh, to a new building on the [[Easter Bush campus]] in [[Midlothian]], 11 km south of the city.]] * [[Moredun Research Institute]] * [[Roslin Institute]] * [[Royal (Dick) School of Veterinary Studies]] (the Dick Vet) * [[Scottish Agricultural College]] * [[EPCC]]'s Advanced Computing Facility
===Hospitals=== * [[Lauriston Building]], Edinburgh * [[Liberton Hospital]], Edinburgh * [[Princess Alexandra Eye Pavilion]], Edinburgh * [[Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh|Royal Hospital for Sick Children]], Edinburgh * [[Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh]] * [[Royal Victoria Hospital, Edinburgh|Royal Victoria Hospital]], Edinburgh * [[St John's Hospital, Livingston|St John's Hospital]], Livingston, West Lothian * [[Western General Hospital]], Edinburgh
===Incubators=== [[File:Scottish Microelectronics Centre, University of Edinburgh - geograph.org.uk - 1150868.jpg|thumb|The [[Scottish Microelectronics Centre]] at the [[University of Edinburgh]] is a centre for [[business incubation]], research and development in the [[semiconductor]] sector; it is a [[joint venture]] between the university and [[Scottish Enterprise]].]] * Edinburgh Research and Innovation, University of Edinburgh * [[Scottish Microelectronics Centre]]
===Research institutes=== * Institute for Astronomy, [[School of Physics and Astronomy, University of Edinburgh|School of Physics and Astronomy]], University of Edinburgh * [[Institute for Stem Cell Research]] * [[Moredun Research Institute]] * [[Queen's Medical Research Institute]] * [[Roslin Institute]] * [[Scottish Manufacturing Institute]]
===Science parks=== [[File:The Alba Centre, Livingston - geograph.org.uk - 350788.jpg|thumb|The Alba Innovation Centre in [[Livingston, West Lothian|Livingston]], West Lothian is at the centre of [[Silicon Glen]].]] * Alba Innovation Centre, a Scottish Enterprise project in Livingston, West Lothian, focussed on micro- and opto-electronics<ref>[http://www.thecourier.co.uk/business/news/boots-listing-boost-for-scottish-tech-firm-ambicare-s-acne-device-1.556584 "Boots listing boost for Scottish tech firm Ambicare’s acne device"]. By Graham Huband, ''The Courier'', 3 September 2014</ref> and managed by Innovation Centres Scotland. It is a subsidiary of Lanarkshire Enterprise Services.<ref>[http://www.scotsman.com/business/management/numbers-double-at-technology-incubator-1-2960341 Numbers double at technology incubator - The Scotsman<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[BioCampus]], Midlothian, focussed on [[biomanufacturing]] * [[Edinburgh BioQuarter]], focussed on life sciences * Edinburgh Technopole, Midlothian, a general science park * Heriot-Watt Research Park, Edinburgh, a general science park * [[Pentlands Science Park]], Midlothian, focussed on [[animal health]] and [[Animal welfare|welfare]] * [[Roslin BioCentre]], Midlothian, focussed on [[animal health science]]
===Technology transfer organisations=== * [[Artificial Intelligence Applications Institute]] * [[Edinburgh Technology Transfer Centre]] * [[Heriot-Watt Technology and Research Services]] * [[Moredun Scientific]] * [[Roslin Cellab]]
===Universities=== [[File:Queen Margaret University main building.jpg|thumb|The new [[Queen Margaret University]] campus in [[Musselburgh]], [[East Lothian]], opened in 2008, is the first new university campus in Scotland in forty years.]] * [[Edinburgh Napier University]] * [[Heriot-Watt University]], Edinburgh * [[Queen Margaret University]], Musselburgh, East Lothian * [[University of Edinburgh]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==See also== * [[Silicon Glen]]
